sen.j: 源 為朝（源 爲朝）（みなもと の ためとも、保延5年（1139年） - 嘉応2年4月6日 (旧暦)（1170年4月23日）？）は平安時代末期の武将。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Tametomo (1139-April 23, 1170?) was a busho (Japanese military commander) from the end of the Heian period.
MINAMOTO no Tametomo (1139-April 23, 1170?) was a late Heian-period military commander.
sen.cmt: Unnecessary use of Japanese term, phrasing
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Tametomo (1139 - circa April 23, 1170) was a military commander who lived during late Heian period.
sen.cmt: 形式上の修正を加えました

sen.j: 源為義の八男、母は摂津国江口の遊女。
sen.e: He was the eighth son of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi and his mother was a courtesan from Eguchi in Settsu Province.
He was the eighth son of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi; his mother was a courtesan from Eguchi in Settsu Province.
He was the eighth son of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi; his mother was a courtesan from Eguchi in Settsu Province.

sen.j: 兄に源義朝、源頼賢など。
sen.e: His older brother included MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo and MINAMOTO no Yorikata.
Among his several older brothers were MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo and MINAMOTO no Yorikata.
Among his several older brothers were MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo and MINAMOTO no Yorikata.

sen.j: 弓の名手であり、鎮西（九州）で暴れて鎮西八郎と称する。
sen.e: He was a master of archery (as a weapon); he was infamous in Chinzei (Kyushu) for his violent anecdotes, and was called Chinzei Hachiro.
Tametomo was a master of the bow (as a weapon); because he earned infamy in Chinzei (Kyushu) for his violent exploits, he started to be called Chinzei Hachiro.
Tametomo was a master of the bow; as he earned infamy in Chinzei (Kyushu) for his violent exploits, he started to be called Chinzei Hachiro.
sen.cmt: 原文のリンク先表示を削除・修正し、それに合わせて英文を修正しました。なお、対応ウェブサイト上では「鎮西を名目に九州で暴れて」とありますが、「鎮西」を九州の異名として読むこちらの原文でも意味は通りますので、原文通りに訳出してあります。ご確認願います。

sen.j: 保元の乱で父為義とともに崇徳上皇方に属して奮戦するが敗れて、伊豆大島へ流された。
sen.e: Although he fought bravely together with his father Tameyoshi for Emperor Sutoku in the Hogen Disturbance, they have lost the war and were exiled to Izu Oshima Island.
Although he and his father Tameyoshi fought bravely for Emperor Sutoku's faction during the Hogen Disturbance, they were defeated and exiled to Izu Oshima Island.
Although he and his father Tameyoshi fought bravely for the Retired Emperor Sutoku's faction during the Hogen Disturbance, they were defeated and exiled to Izu Oshima Island.
sen.cmt: 原文のリンク先表示を修正し（「天皇」→「上皇」）、それに合わせて英文を修正しました。

sen.j: 流刑地の伊豆諸島でも暴れて国司に従わなかったため、追討を受けて自害した。
sen.e: Because he continued to behave wildly and did not follow the orders of the local governor in the Izu Island chain where he was exiled, he was hunt down and in the end, he committed suicide.

Because he continued to behave wildly and did not follow the orders of the local governor in the Izu Island chain where he was exiled, a search and destroy mission was launched against him; in the end, he chose to commit suicide.

Because he continued to behave wildly and did not follow the orders of the local governor in the Izu Island chain where he was exiled, a search and destroy mission was launched against him; in the end, he chose to commit suicide.

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Biography
Biography
Biography

sen.j: 為朝の生涯については軍記物語の『保元物語』に拠るところが多く、本項目も主にこれに従って記述する。
sen.e: Our knowledge of Tametomo's life mostly depends on a war chronicle called "Hogen Monogatari" (The Tale of the Hogen War), and as such, this section is written according to its account.

Present-day knowledge of Tametomo's life largely depends on a war chronicle called the "Hogen Monogatari" (The Tale of the Hogen War), and as such, the following section is mostly based on its account.

Present-day knowledge of Tametomo's life largely depends on a war chronicle called the "Hogen Monogatari" (The Tale of the Hogen War), and as such, the following section is mostly based on its account.

sen.j: 為朝は『保元物語』の事実上の主人公で、その活躍は人間離れしており、そのまま事実とは考えられない。
sen.e: Although Tametomo is the virtual main character of "Hogen Monogatari," all his achievements depicted in the story is far from realistic.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: Tametomo is depicted as the de facto main character of "Hogen Monogatari," yet his achievements, as depicted in this story, certainly cannot be taken as genuine historical facts.
Tametomo is depicted as the de facto main character of "Hogen Monogatari," yet his superhuman achievements, as depicted in this story, certainly cannot be taken as genuine historical facts.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ箇所（人間離れ）を加筆しました

sen.j: 『愚管抄』にも為朝が兄の頼賢とともに奮戦したと書かれており、『吾妻鏡』建久2年8月1日（1191年8月22日）の条にも戦場で射られた大庭景義が為朝を「無双の弓矢の達者」であると証言している。
sen.e: In "Gukansho" (An Interpretative History of Japan), it is depicted that Tametomo fought bravely together with his older brother Yoritaka, and also in the entry of August 29, 1191 in "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East), it is written that Kageyoshi OBA who was injured in the battlefield descried Tametomo as 'the matchless master of archery.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: The "Gukansho" (An Interpretative History of Japan) depicts Tametomo fighting bravely alongside his older brother Yoritaka; the August 29, 1191 entry of the "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East) relates how Kageyoshi OBA, who was shot by an arrow on the battlefield, described Tametomo as 'the peerless master of the bow.'

The "Gukansho" (literally, Jottings of Personal Views; An Interpretative History of Japan) depicts Tametomo fighting bravely alongside his older brother Yorikata; the August 22, 1191 entry of the "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East) relates how Kageyoshi OBA, who was shot by an arrow on the battlefield, described Tametomo as 'the peerless master of the bow.'
sen.cmt: スペーシングを修正しました。書名英訳を補足しました（参考：http://books.google.com/books?id=JqluAAAAMAAJ&q=Gukansho&dq=Gukansho&hl=ja&ei=wZioTLyOF4revQOCncnbDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBA）。人名（頼賢）の誤字を修正しました。原文に対応西暦日付を補足しました。なお、翻訳者による対応日付計算が誤っていましたので、再計算のうえ正しい日付に直しました。参考：http://keisan.casio.jp/has10/SpecExec.cgi

sen.j: このことから、剛の武者であったことは確かである。
sen.e: From such accounts, it is certain that he was a brave warrior.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: It can be deduced from the above accounts that he was a brave warrior.
It can be deduced from the above accounts that he was a brave warrior.

sen.j: 鎮西総追捕使
sen.e: So-tsuibushi (a governmental officer who had rights over political and military affairs) in Chinzei
Tametomo's tenure as So-tsuibushi (a governmental officer who had rights over political and military affairs) in Chinzei
Chinzei (Kyushu) So-tsuibushi (a governmental officer who had rights over political and military affairs)
sen.cmt: 小見出しですので、簡潔に原文通りに戻しました

sen.j: 為朝は七尺程（2m10cm）の大男で、目の隅が切れあがった容貌魁偉であった。
sen.e: Tametomo is a large man of about 2 m10cm, and with his long-slitted eyes, he had an impressive appearance.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: Tametomo is described as having been a huge man, nearly seven feet tall, and both a powerful physique and, thanks to his long-slitted eyes, a commanding face.
Tametomo is described as having been a huge man, nearly seven feet tall, and both a powerful physique and, thanks to his long-slit eyes, a formidable look.

sen.j: 世に聞こえた強弓の使い手で左腕が右腕よりも4寸（12cm）も長かった。
sen.e: He was a famous master of archery, and his left arm was 12 cm longer than his right arm.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: His fame as a legendary master of archery survives to this day; his left arm is described as having been almost five inches (12 cm) longer than his right arm.
His fame as a legendary master of archery survives to this day; his left arm is described as having been almost five inches (12 cm) longer than his right arm.

sen.j: 勇猛で傍若無人であり、兄たちにも遠慮しなかった。
sen.e: He was brave and daring, and was not afraid of his older brothers.
He was both brave and insolent, nor did he restrain himself for his older brothers.
He was both brave and insolent, and did not restrain himself in the presence of his older brothers.
sen.cmt: nor の使い方が不適切（先行する主文が否定形ではない）につき修正しました。

sen.j: 13歳の時、父為義に勘当されて九州に追放されてしまった。
sen.e: When he was 13 years-old, he was kicked out by his father Tameyoshi and was sent to Kyushu.
When he was 13 years old, he was disowned by his father Tameyoshi and sent to Kyushu.
When he was 13 years old, he was disowned by his father Tameyoshi and sent to Kyushu.

sen.j: 尾張権守家遠が後見となって豊後国に住んでいたが、肥後国阿蘇の平忠国の婿となった。
sen.e: Ieto, who was the provisional governor of Owari Province, became his guardian and Tametomo lived in Bungo Province, and later he married to a daughter of Tadakuni TAIRA, who was of Aso clan of Higo Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: After Ieto, the provisional governor of Owari Province, became his guardian, Tametomo lived in Bungo Province, and later he married a daughter of Tadakuni TAIRA, who was of the Aso clan of Higo Province.
After Ieto, the provisional governor of Owari Province, became his guardian, Tametomo lived in Bungo Province, and later he married a daughter of TAIRA no Tadakuni from Aso, Higo Province.
sen.cmt: 原文のリンク先表示を対応ウィキサイトに準じて修正のうえ、対応英文を修正しました。人名の読みを修正しました。

sen.j: 自ら鎮西総追捕使と称して暴れまわり、菊池氏、原田氏など九州の豪族たちと数十回の合戦、城攻めを繰り返して3年のうちに九州を平らげてしまった。
sen.e: He called himself So-tsuibushi (a governmental officer who had rights over political and military affairs) of Chinzei (Kyushu) and behaved violently, fighting with the local lords of Kyushu such as Kikuchi clan and Harada clan, attacking their castles for a few dozen times, and within 3 years, he ruled Kyushu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: Tametomo styled himself the So-tsuibushi (a governmental officer who had rights over political and military affairs) of Chinzei (Kyushu) and acted violently, fighting dozens of battles with the local lords of Kyushu like the Kikuchi and Harada clans and, by repeatedly assaulting their castles came to control all of Kyushu within three years.

Tametomo styled himself the Chinzei So-tsuibushi and acted violently, fighting dozens of battles with the local lords of Kyushu like the Kikuchi and Harada clans and, by repeatedly assaulting their castles came to control all of Kyushu within three years.
sen.cmt: 二回目の解説は削除し、簡潔化しました。

sen.j: 香椎宮の神人が為朝の狼藉を朝廷に訴え出たため、久寿元年（1154年）に出頭の宣旨が出されてしまう。
sen.e: Jinin (shrine administrator) of Kashii-gu Shrine reported the violent behavior of Tametomo to the Imperial Court, and an imperial decree ordering him to present himself at the court was issued in 1154.
The Jinin (shrine administrator) of Kashii-gu Shrine reported Tametomo's violent behavior to the Imperial Court, which in 1154 issued an imperial decree ordering him to present himself at court.
The Jinin (shrine administrator) of Kashii-gu Shrine reported Tametomo's violent behavior to the Imperial Court, which in 1154 issued an imperial decree ordering him to present himself at court.

sen.j: 為朝はこれに従わなかったが、翌久寿2年（1155年）に父が解官されてしまった。
sen.e: Tametomo ignored this decree, but in 1155, his father was fired from his governmental post.
Tametomo refused to obey this order, but then in 1155, his father was dismissed from his governmental post.
Tametomo refused to obey this order, but then in 1155, his father was dismissed from his governmental post.

sen.j: これを聞いて為朝は帰参することにし、九州の強者28騎を率いて上洛した。
sen.e: Upon hearing this, Tametomo decided to return home, and he returned to the capital with 28 strong soldiers of Kyushu.
Upon hearing this, Tametomo decided to fall back into line, and journeyed to the capital with 28 strong soldiers of Kyushu.
sen.cmt: Note that kisan suru means "return to service", hence my translation of "fall into line"
sen.e: Upon hearing this, Tametomo decided to fall back into line, and journeyed to the capital with 28 strong soldiers of Kyushu.

sen.j: 保元の乱
sen.e: The Hogen Disturbance
The Hogen Disturbance
The Hogen Disturbance

sen.j: 翌保元元年（1156年）、鳥羽法皇の死後、皇位を巡って対立していた崇徳上皇と後白河天皇の武力衝突が不可避の情勢になり、双方の陣営が有力な武士を招聘していた。
sen.e: In 1156, after the death of the Cloistered Emperor Toba, the Retired Emperor Sutoku and the Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa, who had been in conflict over succession of the imperial throne, came to the point where they could not avoid an armed crash, and as such, each camp was calling for strong warriors.

In 1156, after the death of the Cloistered Emperor Toba, the Retired Emperor Sutoku and the Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa, who had fallen into conflict over the imperial succession, reached the point where it was no longer possible to avoid armed conflict, and so each camp began recruiting powerful warriors.
sen.cmt: Word choice, structure, phrasing (note that it should be clash, not crash)
sen.e: In 1156, after the death of the Cloistered Emperor Toba, the Retired Emperor Sutoku and Emperor Goshirakawa, who had fallen into conflict over the imperial succession, reached the point where it was no longer possible to avoid armed conflict, and so each camp began recruiting powerful warriors.
sen.cmt: 後白河天皇を「法皇」から「天皇」へ修正しました（法皇になるのは保元の乱後のようです）。

sen.j: 父の為義は上皇方に大将として招かれ、老齢であると固辞したものの遂に承諾させられ、頼賢、為朝ら6人の子を引連れて崇徳上皇の御所白川北殿に参上した。
sen.e: Tametomo's father Tameyoshi was invited as Taisho (general) by the Retired Emperor Sutoku, and although he resisted for the reason of his old age, he was forced to accept the invitation and he presented himself with his six sons including Tametomo at the Shirakawakita-dono Palace of the Retired Emperor Sutoku.

Tametomo's father Tameyoshi was invited to serve as Taisho (general) by the Retired Emperor Sutoku, and although he initially tried to refuse, citing his advanced age, he was forced to accept the invitation and presented himself with six of his sons, including Tametomo, at Retired Emperor Sutoku's Shirakawakita-dono Palace.

Tameyoshi, Tametomo's father, was invited to serve as Taisho (general) by the Retired Emperor Sutoku, and although he initially tried to refuse, citing his advanced age, he was forced to accept the invitation and presented himself with six of his sons, including Yorikata and Tametomo, at Retired Emperor Sutoku's Shirakawakita-dono Palace.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ箇所を加筆しました。

sen.j: 一方、関東地方を地盤としていた為義の嫡男の義朝は多くの東国武士とともに天皇方へ参じている。
sen.e: On the other hand Yoshitomo, who was the eldest son of Tameyoshi and had his basis in the Kanto Region, joined the army of the Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa with the samurai of the eastern regions.

By contrast, Yoshitomo, who was the eldest son of Tameyoshi and was based in the Kanto region, joined the army of the Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa, along with most of the samurai of the eastern regions.
By contrast, Yoshitomo, who was the eldest son of Tameyoshi and was based in the Kanto region, joined the army of the Emperor Goshirakawa, along with most of the samurai of the eastern regions.
sen.cmt: 後白河天皇を「法皇」から「天皇」へ修正しました)

sen.j: 為朝は三尺五寸の太刀を差し、五人張りの強弓を持って西河原面の門を守った。
sen.e: Tametomo carried a sword longer than 1 meter and a strong bow which is said to take 5 people to be handled, and protected the gate facing Nishigawara.
Tametomo carried a sword that was over one meter long as well as a mighty bow which is said to have taken five men to string; he stationed himself to hold the gate facing Nishigawara.
Tametomo carried a sword that was over one meter long as well as a mighty bow which is said to have taken five men to string; he stationed himself to hold the gate facing Nishigawara.

sen.j: 7月11日 (旧暦)（1156年7月29日）、軍議が開かれ、為朝は「九州で多くの合戦をしましたが夜討に勝るものはありません。
sen.e: On July 11, a war council was held, and Tametomo suggested a night attack by saying that 'I have fought many battles in Kyushu, and I believe there is no better strategy than the night attack.

On the eleventh day of the seventh month, a council of war council was held at which Tametomo proposed a night attack, saying 'I have fought many battles in Kyushu, and I believe there is no better strategy than the night attack.
On July 29, 1156, a council of war was held at which Tametomo proposed a night attack, saying "I have fought many battles in Kyushu, and I believe there is no better strategy than the night attack."
sen.cmt: 原文に対応西暦日付を補足のうえ再訳出しました。参考：http://keisan.casio.jp/has10/SpecExec.cgi また、原文文末に閉じ括弧を付し、英文にも引用符を付しました（台詞）。

sen.j: ただちに高松殿（天皇方の本営）へ攻め寄せ、火を放てば容易に勝てましょう。
sen.e: If we attack the Takamatsu-dono Palace (the headquarter of the Emperor's army) immediately and set fire to it, we will win the battle easily.
If we immediately attack Takamatsu-dono Palace (the headquarters of the Emperor's army) and set fire to it, we will easily win the battle.
"If we immediately attack Takamatsu-dono Palace (the headquarters of the Emperor's army) and set fire to it, we will easily win the battle."
sen.cmt: 原文・英文共に引用符を付して台詞であることを示しました。

sen.j: 兄の義朝が出てくれば私が射落としますし、平清盛なぞは敵にもなりません。
sen.e: If my brother Yoshitomo comes out, I will shoot my arrow at him, and I don't consider Kiyomori TAIRA worth even putting up a fight with.
If my older brother Yoshitomo sallies forth, I will shoot him down, and as for Kiyomori TAIRA, he is not even worthy to be my opponent.
"If my older brother Yoshitomo sallies forth, I will shoot him down, and as for Kiyomori TAIRA, he is not even worthy to be my opponent."
sen.cmt: 原文・英文共に引用符を付して台詞であることを示しました。

sen.j: 逃げ出してくる主上の駕車の人夫を射散らして、主上をお連れすればよろしい」と夜討を献策する。
sen.e: We will scare away the carriers of the palanquin where the escaping lord is hiding by shooting arrows, and then we will capture the lord'.
Let us shower the bearers of the Emperor's palanquin with arrows as he seeks to flee, for in so doing we shall scare his bearers into flight and thus capture him.'
"Let us shower the bearers of the Emperor's palanquin with arrows as he seeks to flee, for in so doing we shall scare his bearers into flight and thus capture him."
sen.cmt: 原文・英文共に引用符を付して台詞であることを示しました。

sen.j: しかし左大臣藤原頼長は「乱暴なことを言うな。」
sen.e: However, FUJIWARA no Yorinaga, the Minister of the Left, turned him down, saying 'Do not be so barbaric.
However, FUJIWARA no Yorinaga, the Minister of the Left, shouted him down, saying 'Say not such barbaric things.
sen.cmt: I have changed the English in the quotation into somewhat more archaic-sounding English.
sen.e: However, FUJIWARA no Yorinaga, the Minister of the Left, shouted him down, saying "Say not such barbaric things."
sen.cmt: 原文・英文共に引用符を付して台詞であることを示しました。

sen.j: 「夜討などは武士同士の私戦ですることだ。」
sen.e: The night attack is carried out for the private conflict between samurai.
Night attacks and other such tactics are to be used in private conflicts between warriors.
"Night attacks and other such tactics are to be used in private conflicts between warriors."
sen.cmt: 原文・英文共に引用符を付して台詞であることを示しました。

sen.j: 「主上と上皇の国を巡る戦いである。」
sen.e: This is the battle over the imperial throne between the Retired Emperor and the Cloistered Emperor.
This is a battle over imperial succession between the Retired Emperor and the Cloistered Emperor.
"This is a battle over imperial succession between the Retired Emperor and the Cloistered Emperor."
sen.cmt: 原文・英文共に引用符を付して台詞であることを示しました。

sen.j: 「興福寺の僧兵の到着を待って決戦するべし」と退けてしまった。
sen.e: We shall await for the arrival of warrior-monks of Kofuku-ji Temple, and will face the final battle'.
We should wait for the warrior-monks of Kofuku-ji Temple to arrive and then commit ourselves to one decisive battle.'.
"We should wait for the warrior-monks of Kofuku-ji Temple to arrive and then commit ourselves to one decisive battle."
sen.cmt: 原文・英文共に引用符を付して台詞であることを示しました。

sen.j: 為朝は兄の義朝は必ず夜討をしかけてくるだろうと予見して口惜しがった。
sen.e: Tametomo anticipated and was chagrined that his older brother Yoshitomo will certainly carry out a night attack.
Tametomo was greatly chagrined to hear this, as he predicted that his older brother Yoshitomo was certain to try a night attack.
Tametomo was greatly chagrined to hear this, as he predicted that his older brother Yoshitomo was certain to try a night attack.

sen.j: その夜、為朝の予見通りに天皇方が白河北殿に夜討をかけてきた。
sen.e: That same night, the Emperor Goshirakawa's army attacked the Shirakawakita-dono Palace, as was predicted by Tametomo.
That very night, Emperor Goshirakawa's army attacked Shirakawakita-dono Palace, just as Tametomo had predicted.
That very night, Emperor Goshirakawa's army attacked Shirakawakita-dono Palace, just as Tametomo had predicted.

sen.j: 為朝を宥めるために急ぎ除目を行い蔵人に任じるが、為朝は「もとの鎮西八郎でけっこう」と跳ね付けた。
sen.e: In order to appease Tametomo, Jimoku (ceremony for appointing officials) was held promptly to appoint him as Kurodo (Chamberlain), but Tametomo rejected this offer by saying 'I shall be happy as Chinzei Hachiro as I have been.'

In order to appease Tametomo, a Jimoku (ceremony for appointing officials) was quickly held in order to appoint him a Kurodo (Chamberlain), but Tametomo rejected this appointment, saying 'I am happy to remain Chinzei Hachiro, as I have been.'

In order to appease Tametomo, a Jimoku (ceremony for appointing officials) was quickly held in order to appoint him a Kurodo (Chamberlain), but Tametomo rejected this appointment, saying "I am happy to remain Chinzei Hachiro, as I have been."
sen.cmt: 引用符を二重にしました。

sen.j: 平清盛の軍勢が為朝の守る西門に攻めてきた。
sen.e: The army led by TAIRA no Kiyomori attacked the western gate where Tametomo was defending.
TAIRA no Kiyomori led an army to attack the western gate, which Tametomo was defending.
TAIRA no Kiyomori led an army to attack the western gate, which Tametomo was defending.

sen.j: 清盛の郎党伊藤景綱、藤原忠清、伊藤忠直が名乗りをあげると為朝は「清盛ですら物足りないのに、お前らなぞ相手にならん、退け」と言う。
sen.e: When Kagetsuna ITO, FUJIWARA no Tadakiyo, and Tadanao ITO, who are the retainers of Kiyomori, presented themselves to him, Tametomo said to them: 'When even Kiyomori is not enough an enemy for me, I don't consider you as my opponents, go away'.

When Kagetsuna ITO, FUJIWARA no Tadakiyo, and Tadanao ITO, all retainers of Kiyomori, shouted out their own names in challenge, Tametomo said to them: 'Since even Kiyomori is unworthy to be my opponent, I would hardly consider any of you as worthy foes--begone.'

When Kagetsuna ITO, FUJIWARA no Tadakiyo, and Tadanao ITO, all retainers of Kiyomori, shouted out their own names in challenge, Tametomo said to them: "Since even Kiyomori is unworthy to be my opponent, I would hardly consider any of you as worthy foes--begone."
sen.cmt: 引用符を二重にしました。

sen.j: 景綱が「下郎の矢を受けてみよ」と矢を放つ。
sen.e: Then take this arrow from a low-rank retainer,' said Kagetsuna, shooting arrow at Tametomo.
Kagetsuna shot an arrow at Tametomo, shouting 'Let us see how you like this arrow from a low-ranking retainer like me.'
Kagetsuna shot an arrow at Tametomo, shouting "Let us see how you like this arrow from a low-ranking retainer like me."
sen.cmt: 引用符を二重にしました。

sen.j: 為朝はものともせず「物足りない敵だが、今生の面目にせよ」と七寸五分の矢を射かけた。
sen.e: Tametomo did not move an inch, said 'although you are not worth putting up a fight with, take this as a lesson of your life' and shoot an arrow of 106 cm.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: Tametomo did not budge, and responded, 'unworthy as you are to be my foe, I will give you the honor of your life' and let loose with an arrow 106 cm long.
Tametomo did not budge, and responded, "unworthy as you are to be my foe, I will give you the honor of your life," and let loose with an arrow of about 23 cm long.
sen.cmt: 引用符を二重にしました。Google計算では七寸五分 = 22.7272727 センチメートルでしたので、数値を修正しました。

sen.j: 矢は忠直の体を貫き、後ろの忠清の鎧の袖に突き刺さった。
sen.e: The arrow penetrated the body of Tadanao and pierced the sleeve of Tadakiyo's armor.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: This arrow passed all the way through Tadanao's body to pierce the armor sleeve of Tadakiyo, who was standing behind him.
This arrow passed all the way through Tadanao's body to pierce the armor sleeve of Tadakiyo, who was standing behind him.

sen.j: 忠清は矢を清盛のもとに持ち帰って報告し、清盛たちは驚愕して怖気づいてしまう。
sen.e: Tadakiyo took the arrow back to Kiyomori and reported, and Kiyomori and his men were taken aback and truly horrified.
When Tadakiyo took the arrow back to Kiyomori and reported what had happened, Kiyomori and his men were both astonished and alarmed.
When Tadakiyo took the arrow back to Kiyomori and reported what had happened, Kiyomori and his men were both astonished and alarmed.

sen.j: 清盛は部署を変えて北門へ向かうが、嫡男の平重盛が口惜しいことだと挑もうとして清盛があわてて止めさせた。
sen.e: Kiyomori changed the position of his soldiers and headed for the north gate; however, his son TAIRA no Shigemori did not give up and tried to challenge Tametomo again, which was stopped by Kiyomori promptly.

Kiyomori changed his soldiers' formation and began heading for the north gate; however, his son and heir TAIRA no Shigemori was galled by the withdrawal and tried to challenge Tametomo again, but Kiyomori quickly forced him to stop.

Kiyomori changed his soldiers' formation and began heading for the north gate; however, his son and heir TAIRA no Shigemori was galled by the withdrawal and tried to challenge Tametomo again, but Kiyomori quickly forced him to stop.

sen.j: 剛の者の伊賀国の住人山田伊行は矢一本で引き退くのは口惜しいと思い、進み出て名乗りをあげて射かけた。
sen.e: Koreyuki YAMADA, a brave warrior from Iga Province, was frustrated that they had to retreat after shooting only an arrow, and stepped forward and presented himself to shoot at Tametomo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: Koreyuki YAMADA, a brave warrior from Iga Province, was also galled that they were retreating after shooting only a single arrow, so he stepped forward and announced his name before shooting at Tametomo.

Koreyuki YAMADA, a brave warrior from Iga Province, was also galled that they were retreating after shooting only a single arrow, so he stepped forward and announced his name before shooting at Tametomo.

sen.j: しかし一の矢を損じ、二の矢をつがえるところを為朝に射落とされてしまった。
sen.e: However, he missed his first arrow, and while putting the second arrow in his bow, he was shot down by Tametomo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: However, his first shot missed, and he was shot by Tametomo while still nocking his second arrow.
However, his first shot missed, and he was shot by Tametomo while still nocking his second arrow.

sen.j: 清盛に代わって兄の義朝の手勢が攻め寄せ、郎党の鎌田政清が進み出で名乗りを上げた。
sen.e: While Kiyomori retreated, the soldiers of his older brother Yoshitomo advanced, and his retainer Masakiyo KAMATA presented himself in front of Tametomo.
The soldiers of Tametomo's older brother Yoshitomo advanced to replace the forces of the retreating Kiyomori, and Yoshitomo's retainer Masakiyo KAMATA announced his name in challenge to Tametomo.
The soldiers of Tametomo's older brother Yoshitomo advanced to replace the forces of the retreating Kiyomori, and Yoshitomo's retainer Masakiyo KAMATA announced his name in challenge to Tametomo.

sen.j: 為朝は「主人の前から立ち去れ」と言い返すが、政清は「主人ではあったが、今は違勅の凶徒」と言うや矢を放ち、為朝の兜に当たる。
sen.e: Tametomo said to him: 'Move away, you are standing in front of your own lord', but Masakiyo replied: 'You used to be my lord, but now you are just a thug who went against the Emperor's will', and shot an arrow which hit the head armor of Tametomo.

Tametomo said to him: 'Begone, you who dare to stand against your own lord', but Masakiyo replied, 'You were my lord once, but now you are just a thug who opposes the Emperor's will,' and shot an arrow which hit Tametomo's helmet.

Tametomo said to him: "Begone, you who dare to stand against your own lord," but Masakiyo replied, "You were my lord once, but now you are just a thug who opposes the Emperor's will," and shot an arrow which hit Tametomo's helmet.
sen.cmt: 引用符を二重にしました。

sen.j: これに為朝は激怒して「お前なぞ矢の無駄だ、手打ちにしてくれる」と鎮西の強者28騎を率いて斬り込みをかけた。
sen.e: Tametomo was infuriated by this, saying: 'I will not waste even an arrow on someone like you; I will personally severe off your head', and attacked the army of Masakiyo by sending 28 strong warriors of Chinzei (Kyushu).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: Tametomo was infuriated by this, saying, 'I will not waste an arrow on one such as you; I will kill you with my own hands,' and charged into the midst of Masakiyo's forces leading his 28 strong warriors of Chinzei (Kyushu).

Tametomo was infuriated by this, saying, "I will not waste an arrow on one such as you; I will kill you with my own hands," and charged into the midst of Masakiyo's forces leading his 28 strong warriors of Chinzei (Kyushu).
sen.cmt: 引用符を二重にしました。

sen.j: 政清は敵わずと逃げ出し、「これほどの敵には遭ったことがございません」と義朝に報告した。
sen.e: Masakiyo escaped without putting up a fight, and reported to Yoshitomo: 'I have never seen a horrifying enemy like him'.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: Masakiyo escaped without putting up a fight, and reported to Yoshitomo that 'I have never seen a more terrifying enemy.'
Masakiyo escaped without putting up a fight, and reported to Yoshitomo that "I have never seen a more terrifying enemy."
sen.cmt: 引用符を二重にしました。

sen.j: 義朝は「馬上の技は坂東武者の方が上である」と坂東武者200騎を率いて攻めかかり乱戦となった。
sen.e: Yoshitomo said: 'For the battle on horseback, Bando musha (warriors from the eastern regions) are better than them', and advanced to attack with 200 Bando musha on horseback, which led to a fierce battle.
Yoshitomo replied, 'When fighting on horseback, warriors from the Kanto have greater skill,' and led 200 such mounted Kanto warriors in an attack on Tametomo, which led to a fierce battle.
Yoshitomo replied, 'When fighting on horseback, warriors from the Kanto have greater skill,' and led 200 such mounted Kanto warriors in an attack on Tametomo, which led to a fierce battle.
sen.cmt: 引用符を二重にしました。

sen.j: 義朝は「勅命である。」
sen.e: Yoshitomo shouted: 'This is an imperial command.
Yoshitomo shouted, 'This is an imperial command.
Yoshitomo shouted, "This is an imperial command."
sen.cmt: 原文・英文共に文末に閉じ括弧を加えました。

sen.j: 義朝は「退散せよ」と大声をあげるが、為朝は「こちらは院宣をお受けしている」と言い返した。
sen.e: You must retreat', but Tametomo replied: 'We act according to the command from the Retired Emperor'.
You must retreat,' but Tametomo replied, 'We are acting under the orders of the Retired Emperor.'
He continued, "You must retreat," but Tametomo replied, "We are acting under the orders of the Retired Emperor."
sen.cmt: 原文に括弧・英文に引用符を加えました。英文冒頭にHe continued,を補足しました。

sen.j: 義朝は「兄に弓を引けば神仏の加護を失うぞ」と言うと、為朝は「では、父（為義）に弓を引くことはどうなのか」と言い返し、義朝は言葉に窮してしまった。
sen.e: Yoshitomo said: 'If you shoot an arrow at your own older brother, you will no longer receive the grace of Buddha and gods', but Tametomo replied: 'Then what about shooting an arrow at your own father (Tameyoshi)?', at which, Yoshitomo was unable to make a reply.

Yoshitomo said, 'If you raise your bow against your own older brother, you will no longer receive the grace of Buddha or the gods,' but Tametomo replied: 'And what of raising your bow against your own father (Tameyoshi)?' for which Yoshitomo had no reply.

Yoshitomo said, "If you raise your bow against your own older brother, you will no longer receive the grace of Buddha or the gods," but Tametomo replied: "And what of raising your bow against your own father (Tameyoshi)?" for which Yoshitomo had no reply.
sen.cmt: 引用符を二重にしました。

sen.j: 再び乱戦になり、無勢の為朝はいったん門内に兵を引くが、義朝勢は追撃にかかる。
sen.e: The fierce fighting resumed, and Tametomo once retreated his soldiers inside the gate as he did not have a large army, but the army of Yoshitomo further advanced to attack.
The fierce fighting resumed, and Tametomo, whose force was very small, briefly pulled his soldiers back inside the gate, but Yoshitomo's forces only continued to press their attack.
The fierce fighting resumed, and Tametomo, whose force was very small, briefly pulled his soldiers back inside the gate, but Yoshitomo's forces only continued to press their attack.

sen.j: 義朝の姿を確認した為朝は射ようとするが、よもや父と兄とに密契があるかもしれんと思いとどまった。
sen.e: When Tametomo identified the figure of Yoshitomo, he was ready to shoot at him, but he reconsidered as he thought his older brother and his father may have a secret agreement.
When Tametomo spotted the figure of Yoshitomo on the battlefield, he made ready to shoot at him, but reconsidered because he thought his older brother and his father may have made a secret agreement.
When Tametomo spotted the figure of Yoshitomo on the battlefield, he made ready to shoot at him, but reconsidered because he thought his older brother and his father may have made a secret agreement.

sen.j: 接戦となると無勢の為朝は不利であり、大将の義朝を威嚇して退かせようと考えた。
sen.e: Because Tametomo's small army has a worse hand at a close combat, he thought of intimidating the commander Yoshitomo, and make their army retreat.
Because Tametomo's small force was at a disadvantage in melee combat, he hit upon a way to intimidate the enemy commander Yoshitomo into withdrawing his forces.
Because Tametomo's small force was at a disadvantage in melee combat, he hit upon a way to intimidate the enemy commander Yoshitomo into withdrawing his forces.

sen.j: 狙い誤らず、為朝の矢は義朝の兜の星を射削る。
sen.e: Tametomo's arrow, without fail, pierced the star on Yoshitomo's head armor.
Tametomo's arrow flew straight and true, piercing the star on Yoshitomo's helmet.
Tametomo's arrow flew straight and true, piercing the star on Yoshitomo's helmet.

sen.j: 義朝は「聞き及んでいたが、やはり乱暴な奴だ」と言うや、為朝は「お許しいただければ二の矢をお見舞いしましょう。」
sen.e: Yoshitomo said: 'As I heard, you are a violent thug', and Tametomo replied: 'Upon your permission, I will send you my second arrow.
Yoshitomo said, 'You are indeed a violent thug, even as I have heard,' and Tametomo replied, 'With your permission, I shall now present you with my second arrow.
Yoshitomo said, "You are indeed a violent thug, even as I have heard," and Tametomo replied, "With your permission, I shall now present you with my second arrow."
sen.cmt: 原文文末に閉じ括弧、英文に引用符を加えました

sen.j: 「どこぞなりと当てて見せます」と言って矢をつがえる。
sen.e: It can hit wherever you desire', and set an arrow in his bow.
I will make it hit you wherever you wish,' he said, and then nocked another arrow.
"I will make it hit you wherever you wish," he said, and then nocked another arrow.
sen.cmt: 原文冒頭に括弧、英文に引用符を加えました

sen.j: とっさに、深巣清国が間に割って入り、為朝はこれを射殺した。
sen.e: 深巣清国 immediately went between them, and Tametomo killed him with his arrow.
sen.cmt: 深巣清国の読み方を確認できませんでした。
sen.e: FUKESU no Kiyokuni immediately jumped between them to separate them, but Tametomo shot him dead.
sen.cmt: I assume this is the correct reading for his family name; his given name seems clear enough.
sen.e: FUKASU no Kiyokuni immediately jumped between them to separate them, but Tametomo shot him dead.
sen.cmt: 人名の読み誤りを修正しました

sen.j: 大庭景義、大庭景親の兄弟が挑みかかるが、為朝は試にと鏑矢を放ち、景義の左の膝を砕き、景親は落馬した兄を助け上げて逃げ帰った。
sen.e: Kageyoshi Oba and his brother Kagechika Oba presented themselves forward for a challenge, but Tametomo shot a whistling arrow by way of trial, which penetrated the left knee of Kageyoshi, and Kagechika helped his older brother who fell from his horse and run back.

The brothers Kageyoshi and Kagechika OBA stepped forward to challenge Tametomo, who shot a signal arrow at them to test their mettle; this arrow smashed Kageyoshi's left knee, tumbling him from his horse, and so Kagechika helped his older brother run back to their lines.

The brothers Kageyoshi and Kagechika OBA stepped forward to challenge Tametomo, who shot a signal arrow at them to test their mettle; this arrow smashed Kageyoshi's left knee, tumbling him from his horse, and so Kagechika helped his older brother run back to their lines.

sen.j: 後に源頼朝に仕えて御家人になった景義は酒宴でこの合戦について、為朝は無双の弓矢の達者だが、身の丈よりも大きい弓を使い馬上での扱いに慣れずに狙いを誤ったのだろうと語っている。
sen.e: Kageyoshi, who later served MINAMOTO no Yoritomo and became gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate), recounted about this battle at a drinking feast that although Tametomo is a matchless master of archery, he probably missed his target at that time because he handled an arrow longer than his height on his horseback, which he was not accustomed to.

Kageyoshi, who later served MINAMOTO no Yoritomo as a gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate), claimed while recounting this incident at a banquet that although Tametomo was a peerless master of the bow, in that instance his aim had probably been thrown off because he was using a bow taller than his height from horseback, something he was not accustomed to.

Kageyoshi, who later served MINAMOTO no Yoritomo as a gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate), claimed while recounting this incident at a banquet that although Tametomo was a peerless master of the bow, in that instance his aim had probably been thrown off because he was using a bow taller than his height from horseback, something he was not accustomed to.

sen.j: 義朝の坂東武者と為朝の鎮西武者との間で火が出るほどの戦いが繰り返されたが、為朝の28騎のうち23騎が討ち死にしてしまった。
sen.e: Bando musha of Yoshitomo's side and Chinzei musha (warriors of Kyushu) of Tametomo's side continued to fight a fierce battle, and 23 out of 28 soldiers of Tametomo's army was killed.
Yoshitomo's Kanto warriors and Tametomo's Chinzei warriros continued fighting fiercely, until 23 out of 28 of Tametomo's warriors had been killed.
Yoshitomo's Kanto warriors and Tametomo's Chinzei warriors continued fighting fiercely, until 23 out of 28 of Tametomo's warriors had been killed.
sen.cmt: スペルミスを修正しました

sen.j: 一方、坂東武者も53騎が討たれている。
sen.e: 53 soldiers of Bando musha, on the other hand, was killed.
By contrast, 53 of the Kanto horsemen were killed.
sen.cmt: Phrasing (note also that I think it unnecessary even to introduce the term "Bando" and recommend the use of the more familiar "Kanto" instead).
sen.e: By contrast, 53 of the Kanto horsemen were killed.

sen.j: 他の門でも激戦が続き、勝敗は容易に決しなかった。
sen.e: Fierce battles continued also at other gates, and neither side was giving away.
The hard-fought battle continued to rage at the other gates as well; neither side was able to gain the upper hand.
The hard-fought battle continued to rage at the other gates as well; neither side was able to gain the upper hand.

sen.j: 義朝は内裏へ使者を送り火攻めの勅許を求め、天皇はこれを許した。
sen.e: Yoshitomo sent a messenger to the Imperial Palace and asked for an imperial permission for arson attack, which was permitted by the Emperor.
Yoshitomo sent a messenger to the Imperial Palace to ask for imperial permission for a fire attack against the enemy's palace, and received the Emperor's permission to do so.
Yoshitomo sent a messenger to the Imperial Palace to ask for imperial permission for a fire attack against the enemy's palace, and received the Emperor's permission to do so.

sen.j: 火がかけられ風にあおられて、白河北殿はたちまち炎上。
sen.e: Shirakawakita-dono Palace went up in flame immediately with a strong wind.
After the fires were set, Shirakawakita-dono Palace was engulfed in flames almost immediately due to the strong wind.
After the fires were set, Shirakawakita-dono Palace was engulfed in flames almost immediately due to the strong wind.

sen.j: 上皇方は大混乱に陥り、上皇と頼長は脱出。
sen.e: The Retired Emperor's side fell into a large chaos, but the Retired Emperor and Yorinaga were able to escape.
The Retired Emperor's forces fell into great turmoil, but both Yorinaga and the Retired Emperor himself were able to escape.
sen.cmt: I switched the order because I felt it best to add "himself" after "retired Emperor", and as such, the sentence flows better in this new order.
sen.e: The Retired Emperor's forces fell into great turmoil, but both the Retired Emperor himself and Yorinaga were able to escape.

sen.j: 為義、頼賢、為朝ら武士たちも各々落ちた。
sen.e: Warriors including Tameyoshi, Yoritaka, and Tametomo also lost their battles.
The Retired Emperor's warriors, including Tameyoshi, Yoritaka, and Tametomo, were also defeated.
The Retired Emperor's warriors, including Tameyoshi, Yorikata, and Tametomo, were also defeated.
sen.cmt: 人名の読み誤りを修正しました。

sen.j: 為義は息子たちと共に東国での再挙を図るが、老体であり気弱になり、出家して降伏することに決めた。
sen.e: Tameyoshi planed a revenge battle with his sons in the eastern provinces, but as he became old and coward, he decided to enter into priesthood and surrender.
Tameyoshi initially planned to fight another battle alongside his sons, this time in the Kanto, but having grown both old and fainthearted, he decided to enter the Buddhist priesthood and surrender.
Tameyoshi initially planned to fight another battle alongside his sons, this time in the Kanto, but having grown both old and fainthearted, he decided to enter the Buddhist priesthood and surrender.

sen.j: 「義朝が勲功に代えても父や弟たちを助けるだろう」と為義は希望を持つが、為朝は反対してあくまでの東国へ落ちることを主張する。
sen.e: Tameyoshi had a hope that 'Yoshitomo will help his father and brothers even by giving up his military honor', but Tametomo insisted to escape to the eastern provinces.

Tameyoshi hoped that 'Yoshitomo will help his father and brothers even if it means forfeiting his distinguished service,' but Tametomo opposed this surrender plan, insisting instead that they fall back to the eastern provinces.

Tameyoshi hoped that "Yoshitomo will help his father and brothers even if it means forfeiting his distinguished service," but Tametomo opposed this surrender plan, insisting instead that they fall back to the eastern provinces.
sen.cmt: 引用符を二重にしました。

sen.j: 結局、為義は出頭して降伏してしまった。
sen.e: In the end, Tameyoshi turned himself in and surrendered.
In the end, Tameyoshi turned himself in and surrendered.
In the end, Tameyoshi turned himself in and surrendered.

sen.j: しかし、為義は許されず、息子たちも捕えられ、勅命により義朝によって斬首されてしまった。
sen.e: However Tameyoshi was not pardoned and his sons were captured, and he was guillotined by Yoshitomo by an imperial order.
However, not only was Tameyoshi not pardoned, his sons were also ordered arrested, and Yoshitomo was forced by imperial decree to decapitate Tameyoshi (his own father).
sen.cmt: I added "his own father" because I wasn't sure casual readers would spot the significance of this situation.
sen.e: However, not only was Tameyoshi not pardoned, his sons were also ordered arrested, and Yoshitomo was forced by imperial decree to decapitate his own father and brothers.
sen.cmt: 父親・為義のみならず、兄弟らも共に斬首されたという解釈で修正しました。

sen.j: 為朝は逃亡を続け近江国坂田（滋賀県坂田郡）の地に隠れた。
sen.e: Yoshitomo continued to escape and hid himself in Sakata, Omi Province (today's Sakata County, Shiga Prefecture).
Tametomo continued his flight, hiding in Sakata in Omi Province (present-day Sakata County in Shiga Prefecture).
Tametomo continued his flight, hiding in Sakata in Omi Province (present-day Sakata County in Shiga Prefecture).

sen.j: 病に罹り、湯治をしていたところ、密告があり湯屋で佐渡重貞の手勢に囲まれ、真っ裸であり抵抗もできず捕えられた。
sen.e: He fell ill and went to a hot spring for therapy, but someone informed and he was caught stark-naked in a bath-house, surrounded by men sent by Shegesada SADO and gave in without a fight.
He fell ill, and while he was convalescing at a hot spring, he was betrayed and the bath-house was soon surrounded by men sent by Shegesada SADO; caught stark naked, Tametomo gave in without a fight.
He fell ill, and while he was convalescing at a hot spring, he was betrayed and the bath-house was soon surrounded by men sent by Shigesada SADO; caught stark naked, Tametomo gave in without a fight.
sen.cmt: 人名の誤字を修正しました。

sen.j: 京へ護送された時には、名高い勇者を一目見ようと群衆が集まり、天皇まで見物に来た。
sen.e: When he was escorted to Kyoto, many onlookers came to see the famous warrior, including the Emperor himself.
When he was led into Kyoto, a large crowd-including the Emperor himself--gathered to catch a glimpse of the famous warrior.
When he was led into Kyoto, a large crowd--including the Emperor himself--gathered to catch a glimpse of the famous warrior.
sen.cmt: ハイフンの長さを揃えました。

sen.j: 伊豆大島の流人
sen.e: An exile to Izu-oshima Island
The Exile of Izu-Oshima Island
sen.cmt: I prefer this somewhat more dramatic-sounding locution for paragraph titles
sen.e: The Exile of Izu-Oshima Island

sen.j: 既に戦後処理もひと段落しており、為朝は武勇を惜しまれて助命され、8月26日 (旧暦)（1156年9月12日）に肘を外し自慢の弓を射ることができないようにされてから伊豆大島に流刑となった。
sen.e: Tametomo's life was saved for his heroic act in the war; on August 26 his elbow was dislocated so that he will no longer be able to shoot an arrow which he boasted, and he was exiled to Izu-oshima Island when the deeds after the battle are out of the way.

Mop-up efforts after the war were already largely complete, so Tametomo's life was spared because of his great bravery during the war; on the twenty-sixth day of the eighth month his elbow was dislocated so that he would no longer be able to use bows, the source of his pride, and he was exiled to Izu-oshima Island.

Mop-up efforts after the war were already largely complete, so Tametomo's life was spared because of his great bravery during the war; on September 12, 1156, his elbow was dislocated so that he would no longer be able to use bows, the source of his pride, and he was exiled to Izu-oshima Island.
sen.cmt: 和文に対応西暦日付を補足のうえ英文を修正しました。参考：http://keisan.casio.jp/has10/SpecExec.cgi

sen.j: やがて、傷が癒えその強弓の技が戻ると再び暴れ始めた。
sen.e: In time, his injuries were healed and his archery skill returned, and he started to act violently again.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: In time, his injuries healed and his skill at wielding his mighty bow returned, and he started to act violently again.
In time, his injuries healed and his skill at wielding his mighty bow returned, and he started to act violently again.

sen.j: 島の代官の三郎大夫忠重の婿となり伊豆諸島を従え年貢も出さなくなった。
sen.e: He married the daughter of the local governor of the island, Saburodayu Shigetada, and ruled the Izu Island chain and did not even pay nengu (land tax).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: Tametomo married the daughter of the local governor of the island, Saburodayu Shigetada, and began subduing the entire Izu Island chain, and even stopped paying the nengu (yearly land tax).
Tametomo married the daughter of the local governor of the island, Saburodayu Shigetada, and began subduing the entire Izu Island chain, and even stopped paying the nengu (yearly land tax).

sen.j: 伊豆諸島を所領とする伊豆国介工藤茂光を恐れた忠重は密かに年貢を納めるが、それを知った為朝は激怒し、忠重の左右の手の指を三本切ってしまう。
sen.e: Tadashige, however, secretly paid Tametomo's nengu for the fear of the deputy-chief of Izu Province, Shigemitsu Kudo, who controls the Izu Island chain, but when Tametomo found this out, he became furious and chopped off three fingers from Tadashige's hands.

Tadashige, however, secretly paid Tametomo's nengu for fear of the deputy-chief of Izu Province, Shigemitsu Kudo, administrator of the Izu Island chain, but when Tametomo found this out, he was furious and chopped off three fingers from Tadashige's hands.

Tadashige, however, secretly paid nengu for fear of the deputy-chief of Izu Province, Shigemitsu Kudo, administrator of the Izu Island chain, but when Tametomo found this out, he was furious and chopped off three fingers from Tadashige's hands.
sen.cmt: Tametomo's nenguは不適切とみて修正しました。

sen.j: 伊豆大島に流されてから10年後の永万元年（1165年）は鬼の子孫で大男ばかりが住む鬼が島に渡り、島を蘆島と名づけ、大男をひとり連れ帰った。
sen.e: In 1165, 10 years after he was exiled to Izu-oshima Island, he went to Oniga-shima Island where descendants of ogres, who are all giants, live, and named the island Ashi-jima Island, and returned with a giant man.

In 1165, ten years after he was exiled to Izu-oshima Island, he went to Onigashima Island, which was said to be populated with giants, the descendants of ogres, and after renaming the island Ashi-jima Island, he returned with a (male) giant in tow.

In 1165, ten years after he was exiled to Izu-oshima Island, he went to Onigashima Island, which was said to be populated with giants, the descendants of ogres, and after renaming the island Ashi-jima Island, he returned with a (male) giant in tow.

sen.j: 為朝はこの島を加えた伊豆七島を支配する。
sen.e: Tametomo controlled the seven islands of Izu, including this Ashi-jima Island.
Tametomo gained control over seven islands of Izu, including this Ashi-jima Island.
Tametomo gained control over seven islands of Izu, including this Ashi-jima Island.

sen.j: 嘉応2年（1170年）、伊豆介工藤茂光は上洛して為朝の乱暴狼藉を訴え、討伐の院宣が下った。
sen.e: In 1170, the deputy-chief of Izu Province, Shigemitsu Kudo, went to Kyoto and reported Tametomo's violent and terrible behavior, and an imperial decree to hunt him down was issued.
In 1170 Shigemitsu KUDO, the deputy-chief of Izu Province, went to Kyoto to complain about Tametomo's violent and terrible behavior, and so the court issued an imperial decree to hunt Tametomo down.
In 1170 Shigemitsu KUDO, the deputy-chief of Izu Province, went to Kyoto to complain about Tametomo's violent and terrible behavior, and so the court issued an imperial decree to hunt Tametomo down.

sen.j: 同年4月（1170年4～5月）、茂光は伊東氏、北条氏、宇佐美氏ら500余騎、20艘で攻めよせた。
sen.e: In April of the same year, Shigemitsu came down with an army of about 500 strong and 20 battleships, sent from Ito clan, Hojo clan and Usami clan.
In the fourth month of the same year, Shigemitsu come to attack Tametomo with an army of about 500 horsemen and 20 ships sent from the Ito, Hojo and Usami clans.
In the fourth month of the same year (in April or May, 1170), Shigemitsu came to attack Tametomo with an army of about 500 horsemen and 20 ships sent from the Ito, Hojo and Usami clans.
sen.cmt: 動詞時制を修正しました。原文に対応西暦月を補足のうえ、英文にも補足しました。参考：http://keisan.casio.jp/has10/SpecExec.cgi

sen.j: 為朝は抵抗しても無駄であろうと悟り、島で生まれた9歳になる我が子源為頼を刺し殺した。
sen.e: Tametomo realized that there is no point in resisting, and stabbed his 9 year-old son MINAMOTO no Tameyori.
When Tametomo realized that there was no point resisting such a force, he stabbed to death his nine-year-old son MINAMOTO no Tameyori, who had been born on the island.
When Tametomo realized that there was no point resisting such a force, he stabbed to death his nine-year-old son MINAMOTO no Tameyori, who had been born on the island.

sen.j: 自害しようと思うが、せめて一矢だけでもと思い、300人ほどが乗る軍船に向けて得意の強弓を射かけた。
sen.e: He thought of killing himself there and then, but wanted to shoot his final arrow, and shot at the battleship which held about 300 soldiers.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: He considered killing himself right then and there, but wanted to shoot at least one final arrow, so he raised his bow against a warship with about 300 soldiers on board and let his arrow fly.
sen.cmt: Phrasing (note that I feel 114 and 115 could easily be combined into one sentence by using a semi-colon)
sen.e: He considered killing himself right then and there, but wanted to shoot at least one final arrow, so he raised his bow against a warship with about 300 soldiers on board and let his arrow fly.
sen.cmt: スペーシングを修正しました。 なお、分割処理後の原文文末が処理前のまま残っていましたので、削除しました。

sen.j: 見事に命中し、船はたちまち沈んでしまった。
sen.e: His arrow hit the target, and the ship sunk immediately.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: His arrow was so well-aimed that the ship immediately sank.
His arrow was so well-aimed that the ship immediately sank.

sen.j: 館に帰り、「保元の戦では矢ひとつで二人を殺し、嘉応の今は一矢で多くの者を殺したか」とつぶやいた。
sen.e: When he returned to his mansion, he said 'I killed two people with one arrow during the battle of Hogen era, and now in Kao era, I killed many with one arrow'.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: When he returned to his mansion, he murmured, 'I killed two people with one arrow during the battle of Hogen era, but now in the Kao era, I have killed a great many with one arrow.'
When he returned to his mansion, he murmured, "I killed two people with one arrow during the battle of Hogen era, but now in the Kao era, I have killed a great many with one arrow."
sen.cmt: 引用符を二重にしました。

sen.j: 南無阿弥陀仏を唱えると柱を背に腹を切って自害した。
sen.e: He called upon and paid a homage to Amida Buddha, and against a pillar, he committed suicide by disembowelment.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: After reciting the nenbutsu (a prayer in homage to Amitabha, or Amida the Buddha), he leaned back against a pillar and committed suicide by ritual disembowelment.
After reciting the nenbutsu (a prayer in homage to Amitabha, or Amida), he leaned back against a pillar and committed suicide by ritual disembowelment.
sen.cmt: 阿弥陀は仏陀ではなく如来ですので、the Buddhaは削除しました。

sen.j: 享年33。
sen.e: He was 33 years old.
He was 33 years old.
He was 33 years old at his death.

sen.j: 追討軍は為朝を恐れてなかなか上陸しなかったが、加藤景廉が既に自害していると見極め薙刀をもって為朝の首をはねた。
sen.e: The army did not land on the island for a while, fearing Tametomo, but Kagekado KATO understood that he already committed suicide, and he cut off Tametomo's head using naginata (a long pole with a sharp curving sword).

The imperial army would not land on the island for quite some time out of fear of Tametomo, but Kagekado KATO, ascertaining that he had already committed suicide, went and cut off Tametomo's head using his naginata (halberd).

The imperial army would not land on the island for quite some time out of fear of Tametomo, but Kagekado KATO, ascertaining that he had already committed suicide, went and cut off Tametomo's head using his naginata (halberd).

sen.j: 没年は治承元年（1177年）ともされる（『尊卑分脈』）。
sen.e: The year of his death is also said to be 1177 ("Sonpibunmyaku").
Some (for example, the "Sonpibunmyaku") have claimed that Tametomo actually died in 1177.
According to "Sonpibunmyaku" (literally, Bloodlines of Noble and Base), it is said that Tametomo actually died in 1177.
sen.cmt: 書名英訳を補足し、表現を修正しました。

sen.j: 大島では為朝は現代でも親しまれている。
sen.e: Even now, Tametomo is popular in Oshima Island.
Tametomo remains popular on Oshima Island even today.
Tametomo remains popular on Oshima Island even today.

sen.j: 為朝の碑も建てられている。
sen.e: There is a monument to commemorate Tametomo's life there.
The island has erected a monument to commemorate Tametomo's life.
The island has erected a monument to commemorate Tametomo's life.

sen.j: 結婚で移り住んできた本土出身の男性を為朝の剛勇ぶりにあやかってもらおうと「ためともさん」と呼んでいる。
sen.e: In the island, men who moved in from the mainland for marriage are called 'Tametomo-san,' so that they may follow the example of Tametomo's bravery.
On the island, men who moved to the island from the mainland for marriage are called 'Tametomo-san' in the hopes that they will follow the example of Tametomo's tremendous bravery.
On the island, men who moved to the island from the mainland for marriage are called 'Tametomo-san' in the hopes that they will follow the example of Tametomo's tremendous bravery.

sen.j: 為朝の武威痘鬼神を退く図
sen.e: Picture of Tametomo beating 武威痘鬼神
sen.cmt: 武威痘鬼神の読み方を確認できませんでした。
sen.e: The Picture of Tametomo the Great Warrior Driving Back the Fierce God of Smallpox
The Picture of Tametomo the Great Warrior Driving Back the Fierce God of Smallpox
sen.cmt: OK. 原文冒頭の括弧を削除しました

sen.j: 足立郡宮内村（現在の北本市宮内）の大島氏は、新編風土記に「大膳亮久家なるものあり。」
sen.e: Oshima Clan in Miyauchi Village, Adachi County (today's Miyauchi, Kitamoto City) was described in Shinpen Fudoki as follows: 'There was a man called Hisaie DAIZEN-NO-SUKE.
The Oshima Clan of Miyauchi Village, Adachi County (present-day Miyauchi, Kitamoto City) was described in the Shinpen Fudoki as follows: 'There was a man called Hisaie DAIZEN-NO-SUKE.

The Oshima Clan of Miyauchi-mura Village, Adachi-gun County (present-day Miyauchi, Kitamoto City) was described in "Shinpen Fudoki" (literally, a new edition of records of the culture and geography of the province) as follows: "There was a man called Daizen-no-suke Hisaie."
sen.cmt: 原文文末に閉じ括弧を付し、英文の引用符を二重にしました。大膳亮は名字ではなく役職名ですので、大文字表記をやめました。

sen.j: 「本国伊豆を領して大島に住し、永正 大永の頃、小田原北条に属して武州に住し戦功ありて、永禄七年甲子の感状を賜う。」
sen.e: He ruled Izu Province and lived in Oshima Island, and during Eisho and Taiei eras, he served Hojo clan of Odawara, and lived in Bushu, and he received a letter of commendation for his distinguished war service in November 1564.

He ruled Izu Province and lived in Oshima Island, and during the Eisho and Taiei eras, he lived in Bushu and served the Hojo clan of Odawara, receiving a letter of commendation for his distinguished war service in the eleventh month of the seventh year of the Eiroku era.
sen.cmt: Phrasing (also, this date seems questionable given the context so I have replaced it with the era name)
sen.e: "He ruled Izu Province and lived in Oshima Island, and during the Eisho and Taiei eras, he lived in Bushu and served the Hojo clan of Odawara, receiving a letter of commendation for his distinguished war service in the eleventh month of the seventh year of the Eiroku era."
sen.cmt: 原文に括弧、英文に引用符を加えました

sen.j: 「その外 槍二筋を持ち伝えり。」
sen.e: He also inherited two spears.
He also inherited two spears.
"He also inherited two spears."
sen.cmt: 原文に括弧、英文に引用符を加えました

sen.j: 「且その頃は鴻巣領宮内村に居住せり」とある。
sen.e: He lived in Miyauchi Village in the territory of Konosu at that time'.
At the time, he lived in Miyauchi Village in the territory of Konosu.'
"At the time, he lived in Miyauchi-mura Village in the territory of Konosu."
sen.cmt: 原文に括弧、英文に引用符を加えました

sen.j: 為朝の庶子の太郎丸と二郎丸の双子は、北条時政にその旨を訴え、源頼朝により太郎丸は大島の領主、二郎丸は八丈島の領主に任じられた。
sen.e: The legitimate children of Tametomo and the twin, Taromaru and Jiromaru, appealed this fact to Tokimasa HOJO, and Taromaru was appointed as the lord of Oshima Island and Jiromaru was appointed as the lord of Hachijo-jima Island by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo.

The twins Taromaru and Jiromaru, who were illegitimate children of Tametomo, appealed this fact to Tokimasa HOJO, so MINAMOTO no Yoritomo appointed Taromaru the lord of Oshima Island and appointed Jiromaru the lord of Hachijo-jima Island.

The twins Taromaru and Jiromaru, who were illegitimate children of Tametomo, appealed this fact to Tokimasa HOJO, so MINAMOTO no Yoritomo appointed Taromaru the lord of Oshima Island and appointed Jiromaru the lord of Hachijo-jima Island.

sen.j: 二郎丸は出家し、承元2年（1208年）に八丈島に弥陀寺を創建した（現在の宗福寺）。
sen.e: Jiromaru became a priest, and he founded Mida-dera Temple (today's Sofuku-ji Temple) in 1208.
sen.cmt: 原文中「1008年」は1208年の誤りです。
sen.e: Jiromaru entered the Buddhist priesthood and in 1208 founded Mida-dera Temple (known as Sofuku-ji Temple today).
Jiromaru entered the Buddhist priesthood and in 1208 founded Mida-dera Temple (known as Sofuku-ji Temple today).
sen.cmt: OK.なお、原文の西暦日付が1008年とありましたので修正しました。

sen.j: 太郎丸は元服をして大島太郎為家（のち為政）と改名したという。
sen.e: Taromaru was renamed as Taro Tameie OSHIMA (later Tamemasa) at the genpuku (celebration of one's coming of age).
Taromaru was renamed Taro Tameie OSHIMA (and later renamed again to Tamemasa) at his genpuku (coming of age ceremony).
Taromaru was renamed Taro Tameie OSHIMA (and later renamed again to Tamemasa) at his genpuku (coming of age ceremony).

sen.j: 戦国大名太田氏の家臣団・鴻巣七騎の1人大島大膳亮久家がおり、小田原の役後帰農して今に連綿と系譜が続いている。
sen.e: Hisaie DAIDEN-NO-SUKE was one of the 7 warriors of vassals of Ota clan, which was a warring lord; he took up farming again after the Siege of Odawara, and the family lineage has been continued to this day.

Hisaie DAIDEN-NO-SUKE was one of the Seven Horsemen of Konosu, vassals of the Ota clan, whose leader was a daimyo (feudal lord) in the warring states period; he returned to farming after the Siege of Odawara, and his family lineage has continued down to the present day.

Daizen-no-suke Hisaie OSHIMA was one of the Seven Horsemen of Konosu, vassals of the Ota clan, whose leader was a daimyo (feudal lord) in the warring states period; he returned to farming after the Siege of Odawara, and his family lineage has continued down to the present day.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ（大島姓）を加筆し、人名を修正しました。

sen.j: 家紋は丸に剣片喰（けんかたばみ）。
sen.e: The family crest is the design of Kenkatabami on a circle.
His family crest featured a sword-shaped Katabami (Creeping Woodsorrel) flower on a circle.
His family crest featured a sword-shaped Katabami (Creeping Woodsorrel) flower on a circle.

sen.j: 琉球の正史である中山世鑑や公選の歌集であるおもろさうしでは源為朝が琉球（沖縄県）へ逃れ、その子が琉球王家の始祖とされる舜天になったとされているが、来琉の真偽は不明である。
sen.e: In Chuzan sekan (Mirror of the Ages of Chuzan) and Omoshirososhi (Interesting Literature), the official collection of poems, which are considered the records of the official history of Ryukyu, MINAMOTO no Tametomo escaped to Ryukyu (Okinawa Prefecture), and his son became Shunten, the founder of the royal family of Ryukyu; however, the truth of the story of Tametomo's visit to Ryukyu is uncertain.

According to the Chuzan sekan (Mirror of the Ages of Chuzan) and the Omoro Soshi (Book of Poems), an official poetry compilation, which together are considered the official history of the Ryukyu islands, MINAMOTO no Tametomo escaped to the Ryukyus (Okinawa Prefecture), and his son took the name Shunten, the founder of the royal lineage of Ryukyu; however, the authenticity of this tale that Tametomo visited the Ryukyus cannot be verified.

According to the Chuzan seikan (Mirror of the Ages of Chuzan) and the Omoro Soshi (Book of Poems), an official poetry compilation, which together are considered the official history of the Ryukyu islands, MINAMOTO no Tametomo escaped to the Ryukyus (Okinawa Prefecture), and his son took the name Shunten, the founder of the royal lineage of Ryukyu; however, the authenticity of this tale that Tametomo visited the Ryukyus cannot be verified.
sen.cmt: 書名の誤字を修正しました。

sen.j: しかしながら、正史として扱われており、この話がのちに曲亭馬琴の『椿説弓張月』を産んだ。
sen.e: Nonetheless, this story was considered the official history, and later it was used as the basis of "Chinzei Yumiharizuki" written by Bakin KYOKUTEI.
Nonetheless, this story was treated as part of the official history, and was later used in this capacity as the basis of the story entitled "Chinzei Yumiharizuki," written by Bakin KYOKUTEI.
Nonetheless, this story was treated as part of the official history, and was later used in this capacity as the basis of the story entitled "Chinsetsu Yumiharizuki," written by Bakin KYOKUTEI.
sen.cmt: 作品名の誤字を修正しました。

sen.j: 日琉同祖論と関連づけて語られる事が多い。
sen.e: It is often discussed in relation to the theory in which Japan and Ryukyu had a common founder.
It is often mentioned in connection to the theory holding that the people of Japan and the Ryukyus had a common ancestor.
It is often mentioned in connection to the theory holding that the people of Japan and the Ryukyus had a common ancestor.

sen.j: 尚氏の権威付けのための伝説と考えられている。
sen.e: It is considered that this is a legend created by Sho clan to increase their authority and authenticity.
It is thought that this was a legend created by the Sho clan to bolster their authority and legitimacy.
It is thought that this was a legend created by the Sho clan to bolster their authority and legitimacy.

sen.j: この伝説に基づき大正11年（1922年）に上陸の碑が建てられた。
sen.e: Based on this legend, a monument to commemorate Tametomo's landing on Ryukyu was built in 1922.
Based on this legend, a monument to commemorate Tametomo's landing on the Ryukyu islands was built in 1922.
Based on this legend, a monument to commemorate Tametomo's landing on the Ryukyu islands was built in 1922.
sen.cmt: OK. なお、原文に対応西暦年を補足しました。

sen.j: 表側の上陸の碑と刻まれてある左斜め下には、この碑を建てた東郷平八郎の名が刻まれている。
sen.e: Below and to the left of the scripture which describes the commemoration of Tametomo's landing, the name of Heihachiro TOGO is inscribed.
Below and to the left of the inscription, which commemorates Tametomo's landing, one can see inscribed the name of the monument's creator, Heihachiro TOGO.
Below and to the left of the front inscription, which commemorates Tametomo's landing, one can see inscribed the name of the monument's creator: Heihachiro TOGO.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ箇所（表側）を加筆し、形式を修正しました

sen.j: 鎌倉時代岩手県宮古市に本拠を置いた閉伊氏の資料には、源為朝の遺児とされる閉伊為頼（為家・頼基・行光とも）が源頼朝より閉伊、気仙を給わり閉伊氏を称したとある。
sen.e: In the historical document held by Hei clan, who based themselves in Miyako City, Iwate Prefecture during the Kamakura period, it is written that Tameyori HEI (also known as Tameie, Yoritomo, or Yukimitsu), who was said to be the bereaved child of Tametomo MINAMOTO, was given the territories of Hei and Kisen, and called himself Hei clan.

According to the historical documents owned by the Hei clan, who were based during the Kamakura period in what today is the city of Miyako City in Iwate Prefecture, a man called Tameyori HEI (also known as Tameie, Yoritomo, or Yukimitsu), said to be the bereaved child of MINAMOTO no Tametomo, was awarded the territories of Hei and Kisen, and took the name of Hei for his clan.

According to the historical documents owned by the Hei clan, who were based during the Kamakura period in what today is the city of Miyako City in Iwate Prefecture, a man called Tameyori HEI (also known as Tameie, Yorimoto, or Yukimitsu), said to be the bereaved child of MINAMOTO no Tametomo, was awarded the territories of Hei and Kesen, and took the name of Hei for his clan.
sen.cmt: 人名および地名の読み誤りを修正しました
